I honestly think that if mutual funds didn't exist and someone tried to propose them today they would be laughed out of the room. "Hey I have this great new structure: You have to pay tax if other people in the fund sell."  Really? (12/16)
Put another way: The tax treatment in traditional mutual funds penalizes long-term investors to the benefit of short-term speculators. It is fundamentally unfair and just plain wrong. (11/16)
It means that, as an investor in an ETF, I only pay tax when I sell the fund. I don't pay taxes because you wanted to put your toes in the sand and drink pina coladas. (10/16)

If a lot of investors want to sell an ETF, an Authorized Participant may redeem shares. If they do, the ETF still doesn't sell anything, because it can redeem in-kind as the article suggests. But rather than being nefarious, this is the only rational way it should work. (9/16)

In an ETF, when you decide to sell, you just sell your shares on the open market to another investor. The fund doesn't have to buy or sell anything to give you your cash, and I am not impacted at all. The only one who pays taxes is you, if the ETF has appreciated in value. (8/16)
In other words, I pay taxes because you wanted to go on vacation. This is insane (7/16).

At the end of the year, the fund will pay out those capital gains -- not to you, because you left the fund, but to me and all the other long-term, buy-and-hold investors who are still invested. (6/16)

Mutual funds redeem in cash. That means when you sell your shares, the fund has to sell stocks out of its portfolio to raise cash to pay you. If those stocks have appreciated in value, the fund realizes capital gains. (5/16)
